Legal_Issue: Validity of Novartis's patent based on utility, obviousness, and sufficiency
Evidence_Assessment: Expert testimonies were considered to assess utility, obviousness, and disclosure
Decision_Outcome: Compound claims upheld as valid; use claims found lacking in utility
Burden_of_Proof: Teva bore the burden to prove invalidity of the patent
Credibility_Factor: Court relied on expert evidence and technical analysis
Legal_Rule: Patent must demonstrate utility, non-obviousness, and sufficient disclosure under Canadian law
Standard_of_Review: Balance of probabilities for patent validity challenges
Grounds_for_Claim: Inutility, obviousness, insufficiency
Outcome_on_Merits: Novartis succeeded in defending patent validity except on use claims
Key_Evidence_Considered: Demonstrated or predicted efficacy, prior art compounds, clarity of patent disclosure
Defendant_Response: Teva alleged inutility, obviousness, and insufficiency to invalidate the patent
Evidence_Type: Scientific data, expert testimony, prior art references
Remedy_Requested: Novartis requested prohibition of Teva’s Notice of Compliance
Outcome: Court granted Novartis’s request, barring Teva from market entry until patent expiry
Legal_Provision: Provisions of the Canadian Patent Act relating to utility, obviousness, and sufficiency

Legal_Issue: Whether Bell's Legacy and Production gears infringe Eurocopter's '787 Patent claims?
Procedural_Stage: Bifurcated trial: liability and damages phases
Evidence_Assessment: Expert testimonies, factual evidence on gear design features
Decision_Outcome: Claim 15 valid and infringed by Legacy gear; Production gear does not infringe; Claims 1-14 and 16 invalidated
Burden_of_Proof: On Eurocopter to prove infringement and validity
Credibility_Factor: Reliance on expert testimony and technical analysis
Legal_Rule: Infringement occurs if all essential elements of a patent claim are present; claims construed purposively
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged infringement of '787 Patent claims related to skid-type landing gear design
Outcome_on_Merits: Partial success for Eurocopter: infringement found on Legacy gear, no infringement on Production gear, most claims invalidated
Key_Evidence_Considered: Presence or absence of double curvature and integrated front cross piece in the gears
Legal_Framework: Patent Act, principles of patent validity and infringement
Defendant_Response: Denial of infringement and challenge to patent validity
Evidence_Type: Technical specifications, expert reports, product designs
Outcome: Injunction granted against Legacy gear, punitive damages awarded; limited relief due to invalidation of most claims
Legal_Provision: '787 Patent claims 1-16
Authority: Court ruling based on patent law and evidence presented

Legal_Issue: Whether NOVA Chemicals Corporation infringed Dow's Canadian Patent No. 2,160,705
Evidence_Assessment: Expert testimonies, claim construction analysis, utility, novelty, obviousness, double patenting, sufficiency of disclosure
Decision_Outcome: Claims 11, 15, 29, 30, 33, 35, 36, 41, and 42 are valid and infringed by NOVA
Burden_of_Proof: On Dow to prove infringement; on NOVA to challenge validity
Credibility_Factor: Dow's experts provided credible evidence; NOVA failed to provide sufficient rebuttal
Legal_Rule: Purposive construction of patent claims; infringement occurs if all essential elements are present
Standard_of_Review: Objective determination based on claim construction and technical evidence
Grounds_for_Claim: Manufacturing and selling polyethylene compositions encompassing patented technology
Outcome_on_Merits: In favor of Dow; infringement established
Key_Evidence_Considered: Strain hardening coefficients, homogeneously and heterogeneously branched components in SURPASS polymers
Legal_Framework: Canadian patent law, including validity and infringement principles
Defendant_Response: NOVA denied infringement and challenged claim construction but provided insufficient counter-evidence
Evidence_Type: Technical expert reports, product testing data, patent claims analysis
Remedy_Requested: Accounting of profits, damages, reasonable compensation, pre- and post-judgment interest
Outcome: Court ruled for Dow; remedies awarded as per Patent Act
Legal_Provision: Canadian Patent No. 2,160,705
Authority: Canadian Federal Court or equivalent judicial body

Legal_Issue: Validity of patent for sildenafil's use in treating erectile dysfunction
Evidence_Assessment: Prior art reviewed, expert testimony evaluated, commercial success considered
Burden_of_Proof: On Apotex to prove invalidity of patent
Credibility_Factor: Expert opinions on obviousness and inventive step
Legal_Rule: Patent valid if meets non-obviousness, novelty, and proper claim construction requirements
Standard_of_Review: Objective assessment of obviousness under patent law
Grounds_for_Claim: Obviousness, anticipation, improper claim scope
Outcome_on_Merits: Apotex's challenge failed; Pfizer's patent found valid
Key_Evidence_Considered: Prior art, expert testimony, commercial success, lack of prior development
Defendant_Response: Apotex claimed Pfizer's patent was invalid and sought to market generic sildenafil
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, expert reports, scientific literature
Remedy_Requested: Authorization to market generic version of Viagra
Outcome: Pfizer's patent upheld; Apotex prohibited from marketing generic until patent expiry
Legal_Provision: Relevant provisions of Canadian Patent Act

Crimes.Crime_Name: Misrepresentation under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Immigration and refugee status claim
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the applicant failed to establish his identity
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: RPD found inconsistencies in identity based on photo comparison
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Sections related to misrepresentation and identity verification under IRPA
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Refugee status due to persecution as a Christian
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Discrepancies in physical features (hairline, ears, nostrils, lips) between applicant and ID photo
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to provide credible and consistent identification documents
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness standard applied to RPD's findings
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Photos that were irrelevant or too blurry for identification
Crimes.Application_Factor: Inability to verify identity without expert testimony
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: RPD's identity finding upheld as reasonable
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Suspected use of inconsistent or false identity documentation

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Immigration and refugee status claim involving identity verification
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Reasonableness of RPD's identity finding against the applicant
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Photo comparison showing discrepancies; other photos deemed unhelpful
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to prove identity
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Physical feature mismatches in official photo vs. current appearance
Crimes.Legal_Rule: RPD may determine identity without expert testimony
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Persecution as a Christian
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Claim dismissed due to failure to establish identity
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Resident Identity Card photo and applicant’s current photos
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act framework on identity and credibility
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Claimed refugee protection but failed to substantiate identity
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of RPD decision
Crimes.Outcome: Application dismissed; no question of general importance certified
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Provisions concerning identity fraud and misrepresentation in immigration context
Crimes.Authority: Refugee Protection Division and Federal Court on review

Crimes.Perpetrator_Type: Individual accused of planning a killing
Crimes.Risk_Assessment: High risk due to nature of alleged crime
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Sufficient for exclusion under refugee law standard
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's story found implausible

Crimes.Crime_Name: Serious non-political crime outside the country of refuge
Crimes.Governing_Law: UN Refugee Convention, Canadian immigration law
Crimes.Application_Facts: Mr. Liang sought refugee protection but faced serious criminal allegations abroad
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Lawful presence challenged due to criminal inadmissibility
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Extraterritorial criminal conduct affecting refugee eligibility
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant's account not credible; Minister's version accepted
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Serious reasons to consider commission of serious non-political crime
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Credible evidence supports conclusion that Mr. Liang committed serious crimes abroad
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Immigration and Refugee Board / Federal Court

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Exclusion from refugee status based on criminal leadership role
Crimes.Procedural_Fairness_Issue: Assessment of expert testimony and procedural fairness in CRDD hearing
Crimes.Evidence_Disclosure_Status: Evidence considered by CRDD including disputed expert report
Crimes.Applicant_Criminal_Background: Accused of leading a criminal organization
Crimes.Risk_Nexus: Criminal conduct linked to flight from prosecution
Crimes.Basis_for_Decision: Implausibility of persecution claim; credible evidence of criminal leadership
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Refugee Convention, Canadian immigration law

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Exclusion from refugee status due to bribery allegations
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether bribery constitutes a serious non-political crime under Article 1F(b)
Crimes.Governing_Law: UN Refugee Convention, Canadian immigration law
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: CRDD assessed credibility of applicant vs. state evidence
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: Less than balance of probabilities for exclusion
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Applicant's story deemed not credible
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Article 1F(b) excludes persons with serious reasons for considering them guilty of serious non-political crimes
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Persecution based on political opinion
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Claim dismissed due to criminal exclusion
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, Refugee Convention
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Denied criminal involvement, claimed political persecution
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Overturn of exclusion decision

Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Exclusion from refugee status due to corruption charges
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Political persecution in China
Crimes.Legal_Framework: UN Refugee Convention, Canadian domestic law
Crimes.Institutional_Action: CRDD finding supported by Federal Court
Crimes.Government_Body_or_Authority: Chinese authorities, Interpol, Canadian immigration officials
Crimes.State_Protection_Assessment: Applicant fled prosecution, not lack of state protection
Crimes.State_Protection_Adequacy: Not applicable – individual was subject to lawful prosecution
Crimes.Perpetrator_Entity: Applicant (alleged public official involved in corrupt acts)

Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant accused of organized crime activities in China and fleeing to Canada
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Presenting as persecuted when likely evading prosecution
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Use and assessment of expert evidence in refugee hearings
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Conduct occurred outside Canada but affects admissibility
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant lacked credibility; Minister's evidence accepted
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Serious reasons to believe commission of serious non-political crime
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Evidence indicates flight from prosecution for organized crime, not persecution

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee claim determination
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Credibility assessment and lack of corroborating evidence
Crimes.Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed, no question certified
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant found not credible due to failure to seek asylum in the US and inconsistencies
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Submitted documents deemed insufficient or unreliable
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to seek asylum during two-year stay in the US
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to provide credible evidence and explanation for delay
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness standard applied to credibility assessment
Crimes.Application_Factor: Subjective fear undermined by delay and lack of action
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Misrepresentation in border or supporting documents alleged

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee claim determination
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Credibility assessment and procedural fairness
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Inconsistencies in testimony and lack of corroboration
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to establish refugee status
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Delay in seeking asylum and inconsistent statements
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Credibility assessed under reasonableness; procedural fairness under correctness
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness for credibility, correctness for procedural fairness
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Persecution in Turkey and conscientious objection to military service
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Administrative law standards in refugee determination
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Claimant failed to justify delays and inconsistencies
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Oral testimony, documentary evidence
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Certification of a question and allowance of judicial review

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refugee claim determination
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Credibility and timeliness of asylum application
Crimes.Outcome: Application for judicial review dismissed, no question certified
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Low credibility due to delay and lack of corroborating evidence
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Oral testimony and submitted documents given little weight
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Two-and-a-half-year stay in the US without seeking asylum
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to apply for asylum promptly in safe third country
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Documents submitted without sufficient independent verification
Crimes.Application_Factor: Subjective fear not supported by objective actions
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Alleged misrepresentation through omission and delayed reporting

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Civil enforcement of court orders
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Can defendants be held in contempt for violating an interim injunction and refusing to comply with court processes?
Crimes.Governing_Law: Canadian law on contempt of court
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Post-default judgment, enforcement and contempt hearing
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Defendants ignored multiple court orders, continued illegal activities, and avoided service
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: Plaintiffs demonstrated willful disobedience by defendants
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Defendants' failure to appear or respond to court proceedings
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Contempt of court includes willful disobedience to a court order; punishable by fines or imprisonment
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Objective assessment of compliance with court orders
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Violation of interim injunction and evasion of legal process
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Contempt established due to deliberate disregard of court authority
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Defendants' continued operation despite injunction, avoidance of service
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Federal Court rules on enforcement and contempt
Crimes.Defendant_Response: No response; non-participation in proceedings
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, affidavits, proof of service attempts
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Enforcement of injunction, sanctions for non-compliance
Crimes.Outcome: Fine imposed and potential imprisonment for non-compliance
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Common law and statutory principles of contempt

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Statutory damages for unauthorized use of copyrighted material
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Can the plaintiffs recover statutory damages under s. 38.1 of the Copyright Act for unauthorized decoding and distribution of copyrighted material?
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Default judgment followed by damages assessment
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Defendants decoded satellite signals and distributed 2,009 copyrighted TV programs without authorization
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Statutory damages awarded at reduced rate
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: Plaintiffs proved infringement through technical and distribution evidence
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Defendants failed to contest claims
Crimes.Legal_Rule: s. 38.1 allows $500–$20,000 per work infringed, subject to proportionality
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Judicial discretion based on fairness and deterrence
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Unauthorized reproduction and distribution of copyrighted content
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Liability established; damages awarded at $150 per work
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Number of works infringed (2,009), lack of licensing in Canada, minimal revenue loss
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Copyright Act framework for statutory damages
Crimes.Defendant_Response: No defense presented; default judgment entered
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Digital records, website content, expert analysis of signal decoding
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Statutory damages, permanent injunction, costs
Crimes.Outcome: $301,350 in statutory damages, permanent injunction, solicitor-client costs

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Infringement via unauthorized decryption of satellite signals
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Can plaintiffs recover statutory damages under s. 38.1 of the Copyright Act for unauthorized decoding and distribution of encrypted signals?
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Defendants accessed and redistributed 2,009 Polsat programs via unauthorized decryption
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: Plaintiffs provided technical and operational evidence of unauthorized access
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Defendants did not challenge allegations
Crimes.Legal_Rule: s. 38.1 permits statutory damages with discretion to reduce if disproportionate
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Equitable and proportionate application of damages
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Illegal decoding and online distribution of encrypted broadcasts
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Infringement confirmed; damages adjusted for fairness
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Volume of decoded content, absence of Canadian licensing, limited financial harm
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Copyright Act and principles of equitable remedy
Crimes.Defendant_Response: No appearance or response in court
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Server logs, decryption methods, broadcast records
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Statutory damages, permanent injunction, full costs
Crimes.Outcome: Damages reduced to $150/work ($301,350 total), permanent injunction, solicitor-client costs

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Unauthorized use of trademarks in connection with pirated content distribution
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Can the defendants be held liable for trademark infringement and copyright violation by decoding and distributing encrypted satellite signals without authorization?
Crimes.Governing_Law: Trademarks Act s.7, Copyright Act s.38.1, Radiocommunications Act s.9(1)(c)
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Defendants used Polsat’s trademarks while distributing decoded content, causing confusion
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Liability established for both trademark and copyright violations
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: Plaintiffs demonstrated unauthorized use of marks in commercial context
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Defendants’ non-appearance weakened their position
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Use of registered mark without consent likely to cause confusion constitutes infringement
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Unauthorized use of 'Polsat' mark in promoting pirated services
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Website branding, use of Polsat logo, consumer-facing presentation
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Integrated application of intellectual property statutes
Crimes.Defendant_Response: No defense raised
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Web screenshots, domain records, trademark registrations
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Statutory damages, permanent injunction, full costs
Crimes.Outcome: $301,350 statutory damages, permanent injunction, solicitor-client costs
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Trademarks Act s.7, Copyright Act s.38.1, Radiocommunications Act s.9(1)(c)

Legal_Issue: Whether the RAD erred in affirming the RPD's decision regarding internal flight alternative (IFA)
Evidence_Assessment: Attack was random; IFAs in Mumbai and New Delhi were viable
Burden_of_Proof: On claimants to prove persecution and lack of viable IFA
Legal_Rule: Under IRPA, claimants must prove they face persecution or risk and lack a viable IFA
Grounds_for_Claim: Religious persecution in India
Outcome_on_Merits: Claims dismissed due to existence of viable IFAs
Key_Evidence_Considered: Existence of safe areas within India (Mumbai and New Delhi) as IFAs
Defendant_Response: RAD affirmed RPD decision; applicants did not challenge IFA findings
Legal_Provision: Sections of IRPA relating to Convention refugee status and need for protection
Authority: Refugee Appeal Division (RAD), Refugee Protection Division (RPD), Federal Court

Legal_Issue: Whether the Trade-marks Opposition Board erred in rejecting Procter & Gamble's opposition to Colgate's trademark registration for a striped toothpaste design
Procedural_Stage: Appeal after opposition and Board review
Evidence_Assessment: Insufficient proof that others used the same stripe pattern; no clear functional intent shown
Burden_of_Proof: On Procter & Gamble to demonstrate grounds for opposition
Credibility_Factor: No material new evidence affecting findings
Legal_Rule: Trademarks must be distinctive, not primarily functional, and capable of distinguishing goods; applicant must intend use and believe entitled to registration
Grounds_for_Claim: Functionality, lack of distinctiveness, ornamental design
Key_Evidence_Considered: Use of striped design, functionality claims, distinctiveness analysis
Defendant_Response: Colgate maintained entitlement to register the striped toothpaste design
Legal_Provision: Section 30 of the Trade-marks Act

Evidence_Sufficiency: Insufficient evidence to support gang membership
Evidence_Credibility: Did not meet police criteria for gang membership
Legal_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s. 37(1)(a)

Dispute_Type: Immigration inadmissibility based on alleged criminal organization membership
Legal_Issue: Whether the Board erred in concluding gang membership
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s. 37(1)(a)
Evidence_Assessment: Reliance on police reports and testimony deemed insufficient
Credibility_Factor: Hearsay evidence not meeting police criteria for gang membership
Grounds_for_Claim: Insufficient evidence for gang membership
Key_Evidence_Considered: Police reports linking individual to gang-related activities
Legal_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s. 37(1)(a)

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with a recognizance
Dispute_Type: Immigration inadmissibility due to alleged gang affiliation
Legal_Issue: Whether reasonable grounds existed to believe gang membership
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s. 37(1)(a)
Evidence_Assessment: Evidence lacked specifics proving active involvement
Credibility_Factor: Reliance on allegations and hearsay without corroboration
Legal_Rule: Membership determination requires credible and trustworthy evidence
Grounds_for_Claim: Lack of concrete evidence of gang membership
Legal_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s. 37(1)(a)

Dispute_Type: Immigration inadmissibility over alleged criminal organization ties
Legal_Issue: Sufficiency of evidence for reasonable belief in gang membership
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s. 37(1)(a)
Evidence_Assessment: Criminal record lacked direct evidence of gang involvement
Credibility_Factor: Evidence based on association and history, not direct participation
Legal_Rule: Standard allows hearsay but requires credibility
Grounds_for_Claim: Insufficient evidence of actual gang membership
Key_Evidence_Considered: Police reports and testimony on gang links
Legal_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s. 37(1)(a)

Crimes.Crime_Name: Reasonable grounds belief in membership of criminal organization
Dispute_Type: Alleged membership in Tamil gang leading to deportation
Legal_Issue: Whether Board applied 'reasonable grounds' standard correctly
Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s. 37(1)(a)
Evidence_Assessment: Police evidence did not meet internal criteria for gang membership
Credibility_Factor: Reliance on indirect associations and unverified reports
Legal_Rule: Person inadmissible if member of organization engaged in planned criminal activity
Grounds_for_Claim: Lack of sufficient and credible evidence
Key_Evidence_Considered: Links to gang-related activities without formal membership
Legal_Provision: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s. 37(1)(a)

Violation_Type: Inadmissibility due to alleged criminal organization membership
Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, s. 37(1)(a)
Application_Facts: Accused based on associations and past incidents
Evidence_Used: Police reports and testimony linking to gang activities
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Did not meet police criteria for gang membership
Decision_Rationale: Lack of credible evidence supporting active gang membership

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of immigration application refusal
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Immigration Officer erred in dismissing the Applicant's Application for Permanent Residence (APR)
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) & Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations (IRPR)
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Inconsistent evidence regarding living arrangements, addresses, financial independence, and family involvement
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate cohabitation and genuine marriage
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Discrepancies in applicant's statements about residence and marital life
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Applicants must cohabit with sponsors in Canada and have genuine marriages not entered into primarily for immigration benefits
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged error by Immigration Officer and breach of procedural fairness
Crimes.Legal_Framework: IRPA and IRPR
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Immigration Officer upheld decision based on lack of credible evidence of cohabitation and genuineness
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Overturn of refusal decision
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Sections of IRPA and IRPR relating to spousal sponsorship and genuineness of marriage

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Judicial review of permanent residency application refusal
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Immigration Officer erred in finding the marriage not genuine and lacking cohabitation
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) & Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations (IRPR)
Crimes.Outcome: Application for permanent residency denied due to suspected marriage fraud
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant provided inconsistent information about address and marital status
Crimes.Legal_Provision: IRPA/IRPR provisions on spousal sponsorship and marriage authenticity
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Marriage entered into primarily for immigration advantage
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of cohabitation and convenience-based marriage
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to prove genuine relationship and cohabitation
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonableness of Officer's decision under administrative law
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None noted; Officer considered all available evidence
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Genuine marriage and cohabitation required under IRPA/IRPR
Crimes.Application_Factor: Inconsistencies in residential, financial, and personal details
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Refusal of permanent residence application upheld
Crimes.Document_Fraud: No explicit document forgery, but misrepresentation through omission/inconsistency

Crimes.Crime_Name: Conspiring to commit an indictable offence (forgery of a Canadian passport)

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Minister's Delegate erred in finding no evidence of LTTE death threats

Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Procedural unfairness and disregard of evidence
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Existence of LTTE death threats and risk upon return
Crimes.Application_Error: Patent unreasonableness due to failure to address evidence
Crimes.Application_Factor: Risk of persecution or torture upon return
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Remanded for reconsideration by different panel

Crimes.Crime_Name: Conspiring to commit an assault causing bodily harm
Crimes.Prior_Criminality: Multiple convictions including violent and fraud-related

Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Sufficient evidence presented but not assessed
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Failure by delegate to evaluate credibility constitutes error
Crimes.Sentencing_Issue: Not applicable – focus on deportation consequence

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Deportation based on danger opinion under IRPA
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Minister's Delegate erred in dismissing evidence of LTTE threats
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Failure to engage with documentary evidence of threats

Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Affidavit and letter not assessed for reliability

Crimes.Defendant_Response: Challenged deportation based on risk in Sri Lanka
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Stay of deportation, reconsideration of danger opinion

Crimes.National_Security_Element: Involvement with LTTE, a listed terrorist entity
Crimes.National_Security_Danger: Potential threat linked to terrorist organization
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: LTTE issued death threats against applicant

Crimes.Nature_of_Acts: Attempt to interfere with legal process

Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Affidavit and letter dismissed without scrutiny
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Issue: Blanket rejection of threat evidence without analysis
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: No assessment conducted by delegate
Crimes.Standard_of_Proof: Balance of probabilities for risk assessment

Crimes.Consequences_of_Action: Deportation if deemed not at risk of torture/persecution

Crimes.Aggravating_Factors: Amount exceeding $5000, pattern of criminal behavior

Crimes.Risk_Type: Public safety risk due to recidivism concern
Crimes.Risk_Nature: Economic crime with potential for reoffending
Crimes.Targeted_Victimization: Applicant targeted due to past affiliations
Crimes.Evidence_Sufficiency: Evidence provided but not properly evaluated
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Failure to analyze sworn statements

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility on grounds of serious criminality
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Section 68(4) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Ferri, a permanent resident, was convicted of a narcotics offense, triggering automatic cancellation of his deportation stay under s. 68(4)
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Constitutional challenge to s. 68(4) raised during appeal
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Whether IAD has jurisdiction to hear constitutional challenges under s. 68(4)
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Criminal conviction record, IRPA provisions, Charter arguments
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: IAD lacks jurisdiction to consider constitutionality of s. 68(4)
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Stay of deportation and hearing of constitutional challenge
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Statutory interpretation of IRPA sections 162(1) and 68(4)
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Explicit statutory language of s. 68(4) limits IAD’s role to factual determinations, overriding general jurisdiction under s. 162(1)

Crimes.Crime_Name: Deportation order under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Constitutionality of deportation provisions in immigration law
Crimes.Outcome: Deportation order upheld due to lack of IAD jurisdiction over constitutional issues
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Violation of Charter rights due to denial of appeal rights after second serious offense
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms, IRPA
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Federal Court dismissed judicial review application
Crimes.Institutional_Action: Cancellation of deportation stay and termination of appeal
Crimes.Individual_Status_or_Claim: Permanent resident seeking protection from deportation

Crimes.Crime_Name: Possession of heroin for the purpose of trafficking
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Criminal prosecution and immigration consequences
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Jurisdiction of IAD to hear constitutional challenges under s. 68(4) IRPA
Crimes.Governing_Law: Criminal Code of Canada, Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA)
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Appeal before IAD and subsequent judicial review
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Conviction for possession of heroin for trafficking used as basis for deportation
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: IAD dismissed constitutional challenge; Federal Court upheld decision
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate IAD jurisdiction
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Section 68(4) IRPA removes IAD's ability to stay deportation upon second serious offense
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Charter challenge to s. 68(4) IRPA based on fairness and right to appeal
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Constitutional challenge not heard; deportation process resumed
Crimes.Legal_Framework: IRPA, Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Ferri argued that s. 68(4) violates Charter rights
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Criminal conviction documentation
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Stay of deportation and constitutional review by IAD
Crimes.Outcome: Remedy denied due to statutory bar on IAD jurisdiction

Crime_Name: Discrimination based on race, color, national or ethnic origin, and disability
Dispute_Type: Allegation of racial discrimination and harassment in employment
Legal_Issue: Whether the Canadian Human Rights Commission breached its duty of fairness by failing to conduct a thorough investigation
Evidence_Assessment: Investigator failed to explore systemic discrimination claims, made factual errors, overlooked key allegations
Decision_Outcome: Commission's decision set aside due to procedural unfairness
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate procedural unfairness in investigation
Credibility_Factor: Allegations by Mr. Herbert regarding discriminatory treatment during RCMP employment
Legal_Rule: The Commission must ensure investigations are thorough and fair, considering all relevant evidence before dismissing a complaint
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness, with attention to procedural fairness
Grounds_for_Claim: Procedural unfairness, inadequate investigation, failure to address systemic claims
Outcome_on_Merits: Not reached; complaint remitted for reinvestigation
Key_Evidence_Considered: Mr. Herbert’s complaint details, investigator’s report, omissions in investigation
Legal_Framework: Administrative law, human rights law, procedural fairness
Defendant_Response: Commission dismissed complaint under section 44(3)(b) without addressing investigative deficiencies
Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence, complaint filings, investigation records
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review, setting aside of dismissal, new investigation
Outcome: Application allowed; matter remitted for reinvestigation by a different investigator
Legal_Provision: Section 44(3)(b) of the Canadian Human Rights Act
Authority: Canadian Human Rights Commission, Federal Court

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Tax collection dispute
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether there are reasonable grounds to believe that granting a delay in payment would jeopardize the collection of assessed amounts
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Judicial review of jeopardy collection order
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Evidence showed use of schemes to evade taxes, false reporting of gains, asset transfers without tax implications, and attempts to shield assets from creditors
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Court upheld the jeopardy collection order
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: Minister met burden by showing it was more likely than not that delay would jeopardize collection
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Respondent's history of financial misconduct and asset shielding reduced credibility
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Subsection 225.2(2) of the Income Tax Act
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Reasonable grounds to believe collection would be jeopardized
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Risk of asset dissipation due to taxpayer’s conduct
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Motion to strike dismissed; order upheld
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Audit findings, asset transfer records, corporate dissolution activities
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Federal tax enforcement regime under the Income Tax Act
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Challenged the order on grounds of insufficient evidence
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary and circumstantial evidence
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Immediate collection action authorized
Crimes.Outcome: Jeopardy collection order maintained; costs awarded against respondents

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Tax collection dispute involving asset transfers
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Is there reasonable belief that delaying collection would jeopardize the assessed amounts owed by the respondents?
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Challenge to ex parte jeopardy collection order
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Respondents engaged in schemes to divert proceeds, falsely report gains, and dissolved companies without repaying debts
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Court found reasonable grounds for belief of jeopardy
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: Preponderance of probabilities standard applied
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Pattern of evasive financial behavior undermined respondent credibility
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Subsection 225.2(2) of the Income Tax Act
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: Reasonable grounds to believe collection would be jeopardized by delay
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Intent to evade tax liabilities through complex financial maneuvers
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Corporate dissolution records, transaction trails, audit reports
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Federal tax enforcement and anti-avoidance provisions
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Argued lack of sufficient evidence supporting jeopardy
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Financial records, audit documentation, corporate filings
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Authorization for immediate collection actions
Crimes.Outcome: Collection order maintained; costs imposed on respondents

Crimes.Crime_Name: Obstructing the Administration of Tax Laws
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Enforcement of tax assessments amid allegations of obstruction
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether there are reasonable grounds to believe that delaying collection would jeopardize the amounts assessed against the respondents
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Post-assessment judicial challenge to collection order
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Large tax debts assessed; evidence of asset shielding via complex transactions and property liquidation
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Court upheld the jeopardy collection order
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: Minister demonstrated likelihood of collection jeopardy if delayed
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Respondents failed to rebut concerns about asset dissipation
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Subsection 225.2(2) of the Income Tax Act
Crimes.Standard_of_Review: More likely than not that delay would jeopardize recovery
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Conduct indicating intent to obstruct tax administration and evade payment
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Motion to set aside order dismissed
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Patterns of financial concealment, liquidation of properties, failure to pay assessed taxes
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Administrative enforcement powers under ITA
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Contested sufficiency of evidence but provided no countervailing proof
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Audit results, asset disposition records, legal entity status changes
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Ex parte application for immediate collection authorization
Crimes.Outcome: Order upheld with costs awarded against respondents

Legal_Issue: Whether there is a conflict of interest disqualifying plaintiffs' counsel from continuing to act
Evidence_Assessment: Information shared during 1990 consultation was public by 1993; no confidential details were disclosed
Legal_Rule: A lawyer cannot act against a former client in related matters unless confidential information was not imparted
Grounds_for_Claim: Defendant claimed plaintiffs' counsel had a conflict due to prior consultation with client on patent issues
Outcome_on_Merits: Motion dismissed; no disqualification of plaintiffs' counsel
Key_Evidence_Considered: Nature and timing of the 1990 consultation; public availability of information by 1993; lack of confidential disclosure
Defendant_Response: Motion to disqualify based on alleged conflict of interest

Legal_Issue: Whether trademark rights can be claimed for an expired patent's design and unproven brand term
Evidence_Assessment: No evidence that 'BARB TIE' was used in Canada to identify the plaintiff's product; oval shape was part of expired patent's preferred embodiment
Decision_Outcome: Plaintiff cannot claim trademark rights for the oval shape or 'BARB TIE'
Burden_of_Proof: On plaintiff to establish valid trademark use
Credibility_Factor: Lack of evidence supporting trademark use in commerce
Legal_Rule: Expired patents cannot be extended via trademark claims if it restricts public use of the invention; trademark requires visible association with goods
Grounds_for_Claim: Attempt to assert trademark rights post-patent expiration
Outcome_on_Merits: Claim dismissed on merits due to lack of trademark entitlement
Key_Evidence_Considered: Patent documentation, absence of trademark use evidence in Canada
Legal_Framework: Federal Court jurisdiction over intellectual property disputes
Legal_Provision: Relevant sections of Canadian Trademarks Act and Patent Act

Dispute_Type: Complaint of sexual harassment and discrimination in the workplace
Legal_Issue: Whether the CHRC erred in dismissing the complaints without a thorough investigation
Procedural_Stage: Judicial review under s. 18.1 of the Federal Court Act
Evidence_Assessment: Applicant failed to submit comments or evidence when given opportunity; CHRC relied on Investigation Report
Decision_Outcome: CHRC’s decision to dismiss complaints upheld
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate error in CHRC's decision
Legal_Rule: CHRC may dismiss a complaint if an inquiry is not warranted based on all circumstances
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged insufficient investigation by CHRC
Outcome_on_Merits: No error found in dismissal; complaints dismissed
Evidence_Type: Investigation report, lack of submissions from applicant
Outcome: Application for judicial review denied; costs awarded to respondents
Legal_Provision: s. 44(3)(b)(i) of the Canadian Human Rights Act, s. 18.1 of the Federal Court Act

Legal_Issue: Failure to comply with court order to provide documents
Governing_Law: Rule 466(b) of the Federal Courts Rules
Procedural_Stage: Motion hearing, show cause order, judgment delivered
Evidence_Assessment: Respondent was served, failed to provide documents, did not appear in court or contact CRA
Decision_Outcome: Found guilty of contempt of court
Legal_Rule: A person is guilty of contempt for disobeying a court order under Rule 466(b)
Grounds_for_Claim: Non-compliance with court-ordered document production for tax investigation
Key_Evidence_Considered: Service of order, lack of response, absence from court, failure to produce documents
Defendant_Response: No appearance, no communication, no compliance
Remedy_Requested: Fine, legal costs, production of documents, potential imprisonment
Outcome: Fine of $3,000, payment of $2,000 in legal costs, required to provide documents within 30 days or face imprisonment
Legal_Provision: Rule 466(b)

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Immigration and Refugee
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the refusal of the applicant's humanitarian and compassionate (H&C) application for permanent residence was reasonable and procedurally fair
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) and Regulations
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Applicant provided limited evidence about her situation in Kenya
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to provide sufficient evidence to justify exceptional relief
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: No significant credibility issues raised, but lack of evidence weakened claim
Crimes.Legal_Rule: H&C decisions are discretionary; court reviews for reasonableness and procedural fairness, not re-weighing of evidence
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Request for permanent residence on humanitarian and compassionate grounds
Key_Evidence_Considered: Limited evidence on ties to Canada
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Discretionary H&C considerations under IRPA
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Second Secretary analyzed evidence and exercised discretion within legal parameters
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Permanent residence based on H&C grounds
Crimes.Authority: Second Secretary, Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada

Crimes.Violation_Type: Non-disclosure of dependent in immigration application
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) and Regulations
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant's mother failed to disclose her as a dependent when applying for permanent residence
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Adult child seeking sponsorship despite non-disclosure
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Mother became permanent resident without disclosing applicant
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Omission constitutes misrepresentation if willful or negligent
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: No interview conducted; no request made by applicant or counsel
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Authority of Second Secretary to assess H&C exemption
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Sparse evidence on best interests of the child and hardship in Kenya
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: No adverse finding, but insufficient proof of exceptional circumstances
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Refusal of H&C application due to bar on sponsorship
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Exemption from sponsorship inadmissibility on H&C grounds
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Discretionary assessment of H&C factors under s.25(1) IRPA
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No justification for exemption due to lack of evidence on best interests and hardship
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Second Secretary, Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada

Crimes.Crime_Name: Cessation of refugee protection under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants returned to Mexico with Mexican passports, creating a presumption of voluntary reavailment.
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Refugee claimants who had been granted protection in Canada
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of RPD's cessation decision
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Use of Mexican passports, travel to Mexico after obtaining refugee status
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: RPD found applicants' claims of duress unconvincing and the presumption of reavailment unrebutted
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Judicial review to challenge cessation of refugee protection
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Voluntary reavailment creates a presumption that was not rebutted by evidence of duress or coercion

Crimes.Crime_Name: Voluntary reavailment of protection under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Cessation of refugee protection due to reavailment
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the RPD’s decision on voluntary reavailment was reasonable
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), UNHCR Handbook guidelines
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Applicants’ use of Mexican passports and return to Mexico assessed as evidence of reavailment
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicants to rebut presumption of reavailment
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Claims of duress were not accepted by the RPD
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Under IRPA s.108(1)(a), refugee protection ceases upon voluntary reavailment of home country's protection
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged duress during return to Mexico
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Possession and use of Mexican passports, voluntary travel to Mexico
Crimes.Legal_Framework: IRPA s.108(1)(a), international refugee law principles
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Restoration of refugee protection

Legal_Issue: Whether the RPD's decision to reject Mr. Huang's refugee claim based on lack of Christian knowledge was unreasonable
Governing_Law: Supreme Court of Canada decision in [2008] S.C.J. 9
Evidence_Assessment: Mr. Huang demonstrated reasonable knowledge of Christianity despite minor errors; RPD focused excessively on these errors
Decision_Outcome: RPD's decision was found to be unreasonable
Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to establish well-founded fear of persecution
Credibility_Factor: Knowledge of religious beliefs and practices as a factor in assessing credibility
Legal_Rule: Standard of unreasonableness in administrative decision-making
Grounds_for_Claim: Persecution for membership in an underground Christian church
Outcome_on_Merits: Claim rejected by RPD initially, decision later vacated on judicial review
Key_Evidence_Considered: Mr. Huang's testimony regarding his religious knowledge and practice
Legal_Framework: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act, Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Defendant_Response: RPD argued that insufficient religious knowledge undermined credibility
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review, setting aside of RPD decision
Outcome: Application allowed; RPD decision overturned and matter remitted to a new panel
Legal_Provision: Section 96-97 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Authority: Immigration and Refugee Board (IRB), Federal Court

Crime_Name: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act Violation
Application_Facts: Applicant claimed domestic violence as persecution in Georgia; inconsistencies in testimony post-2005 affected credibility
Residency_Compliance: Not applicable - claimant was seeking status
Misrepresentation_Element: Inconsistencies in applicant's testimony affecting credibility
Procedural_Issue: RAD's standard of review on RPD's credibility findings
Jurisdictional_Issue: Jurisdiction of RAD and Federal Court in refugee appeals
Evidence_Used: Applicant's testimony, documentation related to domestic violence claim
Credibility_Assessment: RPD found applicant not credible post-2005; RAD upheld finding under reasonableness standard while conducting independent assessment
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim rejected due to credibility issues
Decision_Rationale: No reviewable error by RAD; RAD properly applied deference where RPD had advantage and conducted independent assessment
Authority_Responsible: Refugee Appeal Division (RAD), Refugee Protection Division (RPD), Federal Court

Dispute_Type: Interpretation of inadmissibility grounds under immigration law
Legal_Issue: Whether medical officers erred in concluding excessive demand on social services under s. 19(1)(a)(ii)
Outcome: Judicial review allowed; decision invalidated and referred back for reconsideration
Evidence_Type: Medical assessment, evidence of ability to work in sheltered workshop
Legal_Provision: s. 19(1)(a)(ii) of the Immigration Act, s. 22(e) of the Regulations
Basis_of_Claim: Potential reliance on social services due to mental disability
Key_Factor_in_Determination: Failure to assess whether services would limit access for Canadians
Application_Error: Failure to apply s. 22(e) requirement regarding service accessibility and impact on citizens
Assessment_Standard: Whether social services would cause excessive demand and impede access for Canadian residents
Evidence_Ignored: Samuel's ability to work in a sheltered workshop and lack of evidence on service limitations
Legal_Standard: Proper interpretation and application of statutory provisions in immigration inadmissibility decisions
Application_Factor: Nature of social services required and their availability
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness or correctness (implied by judicial review context)

Violation_Type: Failure to demonstrate well-founded fear of persecution
Procedural delay in claiming refugee status
Governing_Law: Convention Relating to the Status of Refugees
Application_Facts: Claimed persecution based on political opinions and membership in a particular social group.
Two-and-a-half-year delay in claiming refugee status.
Made trips outside Algeria without seeking asylum during that period.
Did not join family members already in Canada.
Residency_Compliance: No evidence of lawful permanent residency; application made after entry to Canada
Procedural_Issue: Delay in applying for refugee status
Failure to seek asylum during international travel
Evidence_Used: Timing and circumstances of refugee claim
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of subjective fear demonstrated by delayed claim
Inconsistent behavior with claimed fear (travel, no prior asylum request)
Credibility_Assessment: Refugee Division found applicant lacked subjective fear of persecution
Decision_Outcome: Refugee claim denied by Refugee Division
Relief_Sought: Judicial review of Refugee Division's decision
Legal_Standard_Applied: Well-founded fear of persecution under the Convention refugee definition
Subjective and objective basis for fear
Decision_Rationale: Applicant failed to demonstrate subjective fear by preponderance of probabilities.
Factual findings by Refugee Division were reasonable and supported by evidence.
No perversity or capriciousness in credibility assessment.
Authority_Responsible: Refugee Division of the Immigration and Refugee Board

Crimes.Crime_Name: Inadmissibility under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Violation_Type: Inadmissibility based on alleged membership in a terrorist organization
Crimes.Application_Facts: Pusat suspected of membership in the PKK, an organization designated as terrorist; officer relied on undisclosed CBSA documents.
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Application for permanent residency under review
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Failure to disclose inadmissibility grounds and deny opportunity to respond
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of disclosure of evidence to applicant
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Found inadmissible due to suspected PKK membership
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Redetermination by a different immigration officer
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Breach of procedural fairness in failing to disclose grounds and evidence

Crimes.Violation_Type: Denial of procedural fairness in immigration decision-making
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Common law and IRPA principles of procedural fairness
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA), common law
Crimes.Application_Facts: Pusat not informed of specific suspicions regarding PKK membership before or after interview; no chance to respond to allegations
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: No pre-interview disclosure or post-interview response opportunity
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Failure to provide applicant access to evidence against him
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Negative admissibility decision based on undisclosed information
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review granted, decision set aside
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Remittal for redetermination by new officer
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Procedural fairness: right to be informed and respond
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Officer failed to uphold duty of fairness by withholding concerns and evidence

Crimes.National_Security_Element: Alleged affiliation with PKK, a designated terrorist entity
Crimes.National_Security_Danger: Potential threat due to association with terrorist organization
Crimes.Threat_Assessment: Suspected active or passive support of PKK activities
Crimes.Risk_Factor: Membership or association with proscribed group
Crimes.Nature_of_Acts: Alleged involvement with PKK, an armed separatist group engaged in terrorism
Crimes.Target_Entity: Government of Turkey and civilian populations (as per PKK's activities)
Crimes.Evidence_Credibility: Based on undisclosed CBSA intelligence; credibility not independently assessed at hearing
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Issue: Undisclosed documents used without applicant’s ability to rebut
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Intelligence reports, organizational links
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not fully evaluated due to procedural flaws
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Alleged membership in terrorist organization affecting admissibility
Crimes.Consequences_of_Action: Inadmissibility and potential deportation if proven

Credibility_Assessment: Found to lack credibility by the Board
Legal_Provision: IRPA s. 37(1)(a)

Legal_Issue: Whether the Board erred in concluding gang-related activities
Legal_Rule: Inadmissible if engaged in organized criminal activity with multiple persons
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged engagement in gang-related activities
Legal_Provision: IRPA s. 37(1)(a)

Prior_Criminality: Conviction for assault causing bodily harm
Evidence_Sufficiency: Sufficient evidence found by the Board
Legal_Provision: IRPA s. 37(1)(a)

Crimes.Crime_Name: Possession of weapons for dangerous purposes
Legal_Issue: Whether sufficient evidence supported gang-related activity finding
Evidence_Assessment: Evidence included weapons possession and gang links
Legal_Rule: Inadmissible if part of organized criminal pattern
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged gang involvement
Legal_Provision: IRPA s. 37(1)(a)

Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Legal_Provision_Involved: Rule 221(1)(a) of the Rules of Civil Procedure
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged breach of procedural fairness by CSC representatives
Legal_Framework: Tort law, specifically the tort of misfeasance in public office
Decision_Outcome: Statement of Claim dismissed without leave to amend
Institutional_Action: CSC representatives' conduct challenged for unlawfulness and bad faith
Individual_Status_or_Claim: Plaintiff claiming damages due to alleged misconduct
Legal_Provision: Tort of misfeasance in public office requires deliberate and unlawful conduct with awareness of unlawfulness and likelihood of harm
Victim_Basis: Plaintiff alleging harm from public officer misconduct

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to disclose change in marital status
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations s. 117(9)(d)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant applied for permanent residency before marriage, married before landing, and did not inform immigration authorities.
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant with disclosure requirements during application process
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Failure to disclose change in marital status constitutes misrepresentation
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Disclosure required during entire application process including pre-landing phase
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over judicial review of IAD decisions
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Application forms, marriage certificate, correspondence with IRCC
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of notification of marriage prior to landing
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not directly challenged, but non-disclosure undermined procedural compliance
Crimes.Outcome: Wife excluded from family class; sponsorship refused
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Overturning of IAD's refusal of spousal sponsorship
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: 'Time of that application' includes period up to granting of permanent residence; failure to disclose marriage precludes inclusion under family class

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Immigration sponsorship eligibility
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Interpretation and application of s. 117(9)(d) of IRPR
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations s. 117(9)(d)
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Judicial review of IAD appeal dismissal
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Marriage occurred after PR application but before landing; no examination conducted
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate eligibility and compliance
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: No allegation of fraud, but procedural non-compliance found
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Non-accompanying family members not examined during principal applicant’s process are excluded from family class
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Spouse should be considered family class member despite non-disclosure
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Timeline of application, marriage date, landing date, lack of disclosure
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Family class sponsorship under IRPA and IRPR
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Regulation validly applied; no error in interpretation
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary evidence (application records, marriage documents)
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Inclusion of spouse in family class and approval of sponsorship
Crimes.Outcome: Sponsorship refused due to regulatory exclusion

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Constitutional challenge to immigration regulation
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether s. 117(9)(d) violates Charter s. 7 rights
Crimes.Governing_Law: Canadian Charter of Rights and Freedoms s. 7; IRPR s. 117(9)(d)
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Judicial review stage with constitutional argument
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Applicant had no legal right to enter Canada prior to permanent residency
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to prove infringement of Charter rights
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Not applicable – issue of law, not credibility
Crimes.Legal_Rule: No breach of s. 7 where regulation applies to foreign nationals outside Canada without status
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Regulation infringes liberty and security interests under s. 7
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Timing of marriage, applicant’s immigration status, regulatory intent
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Charter analysis within administrative immigration context
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Regulation is reasonable limit on rights justified under s. 1
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Statutory interpretation, policy rationale, case law
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Declaration of invalidity under Charter, remedy for exclusion

Crimes.Violation_Type: Use of false documents to enter Canada
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants entered Canada with false documents and made refugee claims that were subsequently rejected
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant due to entry with false documents
Crimes.Misrepresentation_Element: Yes, use of false documents constitutes misrepresentation
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Motion for stay of removal pending judicial review of PRRA decision
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal court jurisdiction over immigration matters
Crimes.Evidence_Used: PRRA assessment, country condition reports, applicants' submissions
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Vague and speculative risk claims, lack of specific evidence on irreparable harm
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Claims found to be speculative and lacking credibility
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Suspension of removal pending judicial review
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Three-part test: serious issue to be tried, irreparable harm, balance of convenience
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Insufficient evidence of credible risk or irreparable harm; PRRA decision was thorough

Crimes.Crime_Name: Making False Statements under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refusal of PRRA based on alleged risks upon return to Sri Lanka
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether applicants demonstrated irreparable harm or serious issue to be tried for a stay of removal
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Claims of forced recruitment by LTTE deemed vague and speculative
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Affidavits, country condition reports, PRRA decision record
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Sections related to misrepresentation and risk assessment in IRPA
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Fear of forced recruitment due to age and family connections
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of individualized risk evidence despite general country conditions
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Judicial review with motion for stay of removal
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to provide specific, credible evidence of personal risk
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Serious issue to be tried, irreparable harm, balance of convenience
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: None; court found submitted evidence insufficient rather than ignored
Crimes.Application_Factor: New evidence considered but found not compelling or relevant
Crimes.Document_Fraud: Alleged false statements in immigration applications

Crimes.Crime_Name: Misrepresentation under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Refusal of refugee and PRRA claims based on misrepresentation and lack of credible risk
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Eligibility for stay of removal pending judicial review
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Claims assessed as speculative and unsupported by evidence
Crimes.Evidence_Type: PRRA report, affidavits, country information
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Fear of harm due to age and perceived association in Sri Lanka
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Absence of specific evidence linking applicants to targeted groups
Crimes.Proceeding_Type: Motion for stay of removal during judicial review
Crimes.Application_Error: Inadequate demonstration of irreparable harm or serious issue
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: No evidence ignored; rather, evidence presented was deemed insufficient
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Serious issue to be tried, irreparable harm, balance of convenience
Crimes.Application_Factor: Emotional harm to family not recognized as irreparable harm
Crimes.Document_Fraud: False documentation and statements in original application

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Administrative
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Interpretation of 'society' in CCRA sections 100-102
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Assessment of risk and deportation plan
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to demonstrate low risk
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Risk assessment credibility
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Protection of society includes foreign societies
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged error in interpretation of 'society'
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Moderate risk of re-offending, lack of supervision in UK
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Federal Court judicial review framework
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Challenged parole denial based on deportation concerns
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Risk assessment reports, deportation plan
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Parole eligibility

Crimes.Evidence_Type: Parole board assessments, risk evaluations
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Reliable risk assessment
Crimes.Sentencing_Issue: Life sentence with no parole eligibility due to ongoing risk
Crimes.Legal_Provision: Section 745 of the Criminal Code, CCRA sections 100-102

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Administrative
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Scope of 'society' under CCRA sections 100-102
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Evaluation of risk and supervision plan
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to show minimal risk
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Assessment of risk to UK society
Crimes.Legal_Rule: 'Society' includes foreign populations affected by release
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Claimed misinterpretation of 'society'
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Moderate risk level, absence of mandatory supervision in UK
Crimes.Legal_Framework: Federal Court standard of review
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Argued against broad interpretation of 'society'
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Risk reports, deportation documentation
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Grant of parole

Application_Facts: Applicant claimed refugee status due to persecution as a homosexual in Mexico
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review of the Refugee Protection Division's decision
Evidence_Used: Alleged formal complaint, incidents of persecution
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of credible evidence regarding formal complaint, isolated incidents not amounting to persecution
Credibility_Assessment: Board questioned credibility of applicant's evidence
Legal_Standard_Applied: Persecution, state protection, internal flight alternative
Standard_of_Review: Patent unreasonableness for factual findings, reasonableness for mixed questions of fact and law
Decision_Rationale: Incidents were isolated and not persecution, state protection presumed available, internal flight alternative existed

Legal_Issue: Breach of procedural fairness due to delay and reliance on post-hearing jurisprudence
Legal_Provision: Section 101 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Procedural fairness under administrative law

Application_Facts: Alcon sought to prevent Cobalt from selling a generic olopatadine product by claiming the 924 Patent was valid.
Procedural_Issue: A Notice of Objection (NOA) was filed by Cobalt challenging the validity of Alcon's 924 Patent.
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient evidence to demonstrate or predict utility across all claimed molecular weights of PVP
Decision_Outcome: The court dismissed Alcon's application, declaring the 924 Patent invalid for lack of utility and overbreadth.
Outcome: The 924 Patent is invalid due to lack of demonstrated or soundly predicted utility and overbreadth.
Decision_Rationale: The court found insufficient evidence to support the utility of the patent across the full scope of claims, and determined that the claims were broader than what was demonstrated or predicted.

Crime_Type: Human Rights Violations and Serious International Law Offenses
Grounds_for_Claim: Denial of employment due to medical restrictions
Legal_Framework: Federal Court Act, Canadian Human Rights Act
Decision_Outcome: Application granted, case remanded for reconsideration
Credibility: Complaint supported by investigation report and response
Legal_Provision: Canadian Human Rights Act
Perpetrator_Entity: Employer (implied), Canadian Human Rights Commission (procedural failure)

Crimes.Crime_Name: Cessation of refugee protection under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicants returned to Mexico with Mexican passports, obtained new ones, and traveled back to Canada
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Voluntary return to country of origin
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Use of Mexican passports, travel history
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicants' explanations insufficient to rebut presumption
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Voluntary reavailment inferred from use of passports and return to Mexico

Crimes.Crime_Name: Voluntary reavailment of protection under Immigration and Refugee Protection Act
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Cessation of refugee protection
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether applicants voluntarily reavailed themselves of Mexico's protection
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Return to Mexico, use and renewal of Mexican passports
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: RPD decision found reasonable for mother; inadequate analysis for minor child
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to rebut presumption of reavailment
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Explanations provided by applicants deemed insufficient
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Section 108(1)(a) IRPA – cessation upon voluntary reavailment
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged unreasonable determination of reavailment
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Application dismissed for mother, concern raised for child
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Travel to Mexico, passport usage and renewal in 2006
Crimes.Legal_Framework: IRPA s. 108(1)(a)
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Applicants claimed no voluntary reavailment
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Documentary (passports), travel records
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Overturn RPD cessation decision
Crimes.Outcome: Judicial review dismissed (with caveat for minor child)

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Deportation and family separation
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Can a removal order be deferred due to child's best interests?
Crimes.Governing_Law: IRPA s. 48, Convention on the Rights of the Child
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant failed to comply with immigration laws but has dependent children
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Family ties, care arrangements for children
Crimes.Application_Error: Removal officer did not adequately consider children's best interests
Crimes.Evidence_Ignored: Children’s lack of adequate care if parent removed
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Enforcement as soon as reasonably practicable under IRPA
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Stay of removal pending assessment or judicial review

Crimes.Governing_Law: IRPA, Convention on the Rights of the Child
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant overstayed visa, has two young Canadian-born children
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Timing of H&C application and removal
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal immigration enforcement vs. provincial child welfare
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Children’s dependency, lack of custody resolution
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient consideration of children's welfare by officer
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: History of non-compliance but genuine care for children
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Deferral of removal based on humanitarian grounds
Crimes.Legal_Standard_Applied: Best interests of the child under IRPA and international law
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Risk of irreparable harm to children outweighs immediate removal

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to comply with reporting conditions
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Enforcement of reporting obligations and removal
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Must removal officers consider children's best interests before removal?
Crimes.Governing_Law: IRPA s. 48, Convention on the Rights of the Child
Crimes.Procedural_Stage: Judicial review and motion for stay
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Children would be left without adequate care
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to show irreparable harm and serious issue
Crimes.Credibility_Factor: Prior non-compliance with conditions
Crimes.Legal_Rule: Removal must consider short-term best interests of children
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Failure of removal officer to assess child welfare
Crimes.Outcome_on_Merits: Pending full assessment or judicial review
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Dependency of Canadian-born children on applicant
Crimes.Legal_Framework: IRPA and international human rights standards
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Resistance to removal and non-reporting
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Family circumstances, care arrangements
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Stay of removal

Crimes.Crime_Name: Failure to meet work experience requirements for work permit
Crimes.Legal_Provision_Violated: Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations, s. 200(3)(a)
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant had no prior cooking experience but possessed relevant certifications; LMO required three years of food service experience
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Assessment based on documentary evidence without interview
Crimes.Jurisdictional_Issue: Federal Court jurisdiction over immigration decisions
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of verifiable work experience in cooking
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Not challenged; qualifications accepted but insufficient
Crimes.Relief_Sought: Judicial review of visa officer's decision
Crimes.Remedy_Sought: Overturn refusal and issue work permit
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Officer reasonably concluded applicant could not perform required work due to lack of experience
Crimes.Authority_Responsible: Visa Officer, Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada

Crimes.Crime_Name: Work Permit Refusal under Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations
Crimes.Dispute_Type: Work Permit Eligibility
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the visa officer reasonably refused the application due to lack of experience
Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Regulations, s. 200(3)(a)
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Applicant’s qualifications credible but experience lacking
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Insufficient work experience despite other qualifications
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Three years of required cooking experience not met
Crimes.Application_Error: Failure to meet explicit job requirement stated in LMO
Crimes.Assessment_Standard: Reasonable apprehension of inability to perform work
Crimes.Application_Factor: Experience requirement was mandatory per employer’s LMO

Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Officer breached procedural fairness by not allowing the applicant to respond to doubts about document authenticity
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Employment letters deemed fabricated due to inconsistencies (e.g., similar fonts, ink-jet printing, duties copied from NOC codes)
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Employment letters
Crimes.Basis_of_Claim: Use of allegedly fabricated documents to meet work experience requirements under the Federal Skilled Worker class
Crimes.Key_Factor_in_Determination: Lack of credibility in submitted documents rather than insufficiency
Crimes.Legal_Standard: Procedural fairness does not apply if concerns arise directly from regulatory requirements or lack of credibility
Crimes.Application_Factor: Work experience documentation for Federal Skilled Worker application

Crimes.Violation_Type: Misrepresentation of work experience through fabricated employment letters
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant provided employment letters with content copied from NOC descriptions and poor-quality printing
Crimes.Claimant_Status: Applicant for permanent residency under Federal Skilled Worker class
Crimes.Procedural_Issue: Alleged breach of procedural fairness in not allowing response to document concerns
Crimes.Evidentiary_Deficiency: Lack of credible evidence supporting claimed work experience
Crimes.Credibility_Assessment: Documents found to be fabricated based on inconsistencies and copying from NOC codes
Crimes.Decision_Outcome: Visa application denied; judicial review dismissed
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: No procedural fairness breach as concerns were based on statutory credibility assessments

Crimes.Governing_Law: Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA) s.24
Crimes.Application_Facts: Applicant's status expired on December 31, 2009; claimed preservation under IRPR s.183(5), which did not apply post-2009
Crimes.Residency_Compliance: Failed to leave Canada as directed
Crimes.Evidence_Used: Conviction record, immigration file, departure instructions
Crimes.Decision_Rationale: Officer correctly identified inadmissibility due to criminal conviction and overstaying; reasons were brief but sufficient

Crimes.Dispute_Type: Criminal inadmissibility and TRP refusal
Crimes.Legal_Issue: Whether the Officer made errors in refusing TRP due to impaired driving conviction
Crimes.Governing_Law: IRPA s.24, risk vs. need assessment for TRP
Crimes.Evidence_Assessment: Conviction for impaired driving, failure to depart Canada
Crimes.Burden_of_Proof: On applicant to justify TRP issuance
Crimes.Legal_Rule: TRPs may be granted under exceptional circumstances at officer’s discretion
Crimes.Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged factual or legal errors in TRP refusal
Crimes.Key_Evidence_Considered: Criminal conviction, immigration history, non-compliance with departure directive
Crimes.Legal_Framework: IRPA and IRPR provisions on inadmissibility and TRPs
Crimes.Defendant_Response: Applicant challenged refusal via judicial review
Crimes.Evidence_Type: Official records, conviction documents, immigration file
Crimes.Remedy_Requested: Judicial intervention to overturn TRP refusal
